description.other_contributors: Silje Ljosland Bakke, Nasjonal IKT HF, Norway

Weber, DR; Leonard, MB; Zenel, BS. Body composition analysis in the pediatric population. Pediatric. Endocrinol, 2012, nov; 10(1) 130-139.
Vale, M.D.C.A; Lisboa, P.L. O papel do tecido adiposo no controle do armazenamento de energia e na composição corporal. In: Waitzberg, Dan. Fisiologia da nutrição na saúde e na doença. Ed. Atheneu, 2013.
Vitolo, M.R. Avaliação nutricional do adulto. in: Vitolo, m.R. Nutrição da gestação ao envelhecimento. Rio de Janeiro: ed. Rubio, 2008.
Fosbol, M.O and zerahn, BO. Comtemporany methods of body composition measurement. clin Physiol Funct Imaging, 2015, ,35, pp81-97.
Shen, W; Wang, Z; Punyanita, M; et al. Adipose tissue quantification by imaging methods: a proposed classification. Obesity Research, vol. 11, n.1, 2003.
Prescott, J.W; Priddy, M; Best, T.M et al. An automated to detect intestitial adipose tissue in thigh muscle for patients with osteoarthritis. Conf proc IEEE Eng. med. Biol Soc, 1, 630-60, 2009.

details.purpose: *To diagnose nutritional abnormalities proposing improvement of nutritional intervention.(en)
details.use:
*To be used to record body composition of both adults and children.
To be used to enter the body composition either manually (adipometer) or automatically (software and image).
(en)
details.misuse:
Not to be used in patients with edema, ascites, dehydration.
Not to be used computed tomography method in children and pregnant women.

details.purpose: To record the measurement of the amounts and percentages of fat, bone, water and muscle in the body of an individual.
details.use: Use to record the measurement of the amounts and percentages of fat, bone, water and muscle in the body of an individual, either directly or through calculation from measurements of skin folds or similar.
details.misuse:
Not to be used to record the total body weight of an individual. Use the OBSERVATION.body_weight archetype for this purpose.
Not to be used for recording the actual measurement of skin folds or other measurements that may be used to calculate body composition. Use other relevant OBSERVATION archetypes for these purposes.

items.items: Measurement of the amounts and percentages of fat, bone, water and muscle in the body of an individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Measurement of fat free mass (FFM) which corresponds to protein, water and minerals.
The methods used to measure body composition.

For example: Determination of body density and volume (hydrostatic weighing or air displacement plethysmography), anthropometrics (e.g weight, BMI, skinfold thickness), conductivity (e.g: bioelectrical impedance analysis,bioelectrical impedance spectroscopy), total body count (e.g: DXA - dual energy x-ray absormetry) or imaging (e.g: Ultrasonography; Nuclear magnetic ressonance, Computed tomography (CT) and Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
Details about devices used to measurement of body composition.
Formula used to calculate the fat percentage by skinfold thickness.
For example: Jackson & Pollock formula and Durnin and Womersley.
Description of the state of dress of the individual at the time of measurement.
Other incidental factors that may impact on the body composition measurement.

For example: menstrual period, oedema and ascites, dehydration, caffeine and alcohool consumption, excessive physical activity, body position, skin temperature and dietary intake, mainly in conductivity techinique (eg: BIA).
Clothing which will not add to weight significantly.
Measurement of four compartments model of body composition.
Measurement of four compartments model of body composition, eg: Minerals, protein, fat and water.
Measurement of three compartments model of body composition. eg: fat mass, lean body mass and bone.
Measurement of five compartments model of body composition, eg: other tissue, visceral organs, bone, skeletel muscle and adipose tissue.
Measurement of five compartments model of body composition, eg: lower limbs, upper limbs, trunk, neck and head.
Assessment of chemical elements eg: N, Ca, P, S, Na, K, Cl ; H, C and O.
Two compartment model with partitions into fat mass (FM) and fat-free mass (FFM).
Adipose tissue is defined as sum of adipose tissue, usually excluding bone marrow and adipose tissue in the head, hands, and feet.
Measurement of subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) mass.
Measurement of visceral adipose tissue (VAT) mass.
Body site where the measurement was performed.

For example: triceps, subscapular, biceps, suprailiac, abdominal and thigh thickness (skinfold thickness); In tetrapolar bioimpedance analysis the eletrodes should be placed at the wrist and ipsilateral ankle.
Measurement of visceral adipose tissue (VAT) area.
Measurement of visceral adipose tissue (VAT) volume.
Measurement of subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) area.
Measurement of subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) volume.
*Measurement of the amounts and percentages of fat, bone, water and muscle in the body of an individual.(en)
*Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.(en)
Measurement of fat free mass (FFM) which corresponds to protein, water and minerals.
*The methods used to measure body composition.(en)

*For example: Determination of body density and volume (hydrostatic weighing or air displacement plethysmography), anthropometrics (e.g weight, BMI, skinfold thickness), conductivity (e.g: bioelectrical impedance analysis,bioelectrical impedance spectroscopy), total body count (e.g: DXA - dual energy x-ray absormetry) or imaging (e.g: Ultrasonography; Nuclear magnetic ressonance, Computed tomography (CT) and Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). (en)
Details about devices used to measurement of body composition.
*Formula used to calculate the fat percentage by skinfold thickness.(en)
*For example: Jackson & Pollock formula and Durnin and Womersley. (en)
*Description of the state of dress of the individual at the time of measurement.(en)
*Other incidental factors that may impact on the body composition measurement.(en)

*For example: menstrual period, oedema and ascites, dehydration, caffeine and alcohool consumption, excessive physical activity, body position, skin temperature and dietary intake, mainly in conductivity techinique (eg: BIA).(en)
*Clothing which will not add to weight significantly.(en)
Measurement of four compartment models of body composition.
Measurement of four compartment models of body composition, eg: Minerals, protein, fat and water.
*Measurement of three compartments model of body composition. eg: fat mass, lean body mass and bone. (en)
*Measurement of five compartment models of body composition, eg: other tissue, visceral organs, bone, skeletel muscle and adipose tissue. (en)
*Measurement of five compartment models of body composition, eg: lower limbs, upper limbs, trunk, neck and head. (en)
*Assessment of chemical elements eg: N, Ca, P, S, Na, K, Cl ; H, C and O. (en)
Measurement of two compartment models with partitions into fat mass (FM) and fat-free mass (FFM).
*Body site where the measurement was performed.(en)

*For example: triceps, subscapular, biceps, suprailiac, abdominal and thigh thickness (skinfold thickness); In tetrapolar bioimpedance analysis the eletrodes should be placed at the wrist and ipsilateral ankle.(en)
